gNHJsBsaKEAFeldRwg2nDA.text: Incredible! Absolutely one of the best meals I have EVER had.I went with two friends and even though I was the only one to order the tasting menu, both of my friends were brought (slightly smaller) portions of the first courses as well. Steak tartare was unbelievable, cabbage rolls were delicious, and my venison was tender and tasty. Between us we had 3 first courses, soup, 3 different mains, and 2 desserts and every single thing was delicious.The decor and the waitstaff are warm and welcoming. Really an all-around excellent place. I will be going back again as soon as I can.

wL__5RpNQPXHzkGaW4PEXQ.text: My favorite place in London. Lovely place to warm up at dusk on a winter night with friends, great pierogis and outstanding soup ladled tableside.

EAcv0urFVYtwNbwrFF_IHA.text: This polish restaurant provides a welcome change from the overhyped and overtrendy South Kensington dining scene. Come here for a late and languid Sunday lunch. Unpretentious eastern European food with a Soviet era ambiance, in a good way. Smiling waitresses straight from the mother country. Plastic table clothes. Life doesn't get much better.

wR4hMo1NgTsYdKLYNf_9BQ.text: Daquise is comfort. Comfort food in a comfortable environment. When you walk in, you immediately feel like you're part of the family who owns the restaurant. The vegetarian polish plate is a dream come true. I never had anything quite so amazing before. (I was tempted to lick the plate clean.) Happiness is Daquise.

U0gDR9AMLaKF2AbMG-nFiQ.text: This relatively small and historic restaurant is a real gem based on a recent Saturday evening visit.  The waiter- recommended wine was excellent, and the salad was fresh, cold and had a nice variety of tomatoes and cucumbers.  Despite the waiter's somewhat odd recommendation after we informed him we heard the pierogies were delicious (he countered that we should order the salmon special), we had the potato/cheese pierogies as an appetizer.  They were fabulous-not at all heavy but light, lightly cooked and delicious.  For main courses, we tried the lamb and a pan fried cod.  Both were nicely prepared and also very good.  Fortunately, we saved room for dessert and more pierogies-these were stuffed with strawberries and were also fantastic.  The waiter was attentive but somewhat standoffish after we rejected his suggestions for appetizers and main, but not enough to ruin a great meal and experience.

xMuHQZfaheWeEtqCDv-YtQ.text: Husband and I just went to daquise for the second time.  We were afraid because some people had said it had changed hands.  But I appreciate the care of the new place.  They bring a lot of ingredients from Poland and they taste delicious.  Best herring I ever ate and the service is an interesting blend of homey and highly personal and elegant.  I want the restaurant to succeed.  We've had the herring, the duck main dish, yum, the stuffed cabbage which was good.  Everyone seems to order dumplings but I think you can do better than the dumplings.  Have vodka with your herring

e7yCz5bDOXAKGV6qfaqbSA.text: I'm sorry to say that I share in the disappointment of these other reviews. I live in the US and have been visiting the Daquise whenever I am London, usually twice a year, since the 1980s. It always had been a delightful experience to dine at the Daquise. It's charm stayed intact over the years and that was so reassuring. The food was wonderful and perfect for a late lunch after visiting the museums. It's a shame that the new owners didn't have the understanding to realize that they were buying a tradition and not just a shell. It was a sad experience to go there and eat overpriced food that wasn't up to the previous standard by any means, and to experience the loss of the once inviting ambiance. Needless to say, I won't be going back.

n7SvZ8GgTflSbk3sI-BepA.text: Excellent east European restaurant at a decent price near South Kensington tube station. Been there lots of times in last 2 years or so for Saturday lunch and post Prom meals. Don't expect luxurious interior - it's clean and functional but very acceptable. Services is good. Menu is unchangkng and varied. Not been disappointed by anything yet. As you might expect, there is little by way of vegetarian - though the option they do have is good. For an affordable interesting meal in the area it's a good choice.

R4VYF5POgtf7W_1evvNTcA.text: I go to Daquise for the atmosphere as much as the food.In the 1970s when South Kensington was home to Poland's Government in Exile Daquise was a hive of Polish political intrigue, and although you can no longer spot a film star of pre-war Polish cinema, the cafe and restaurant retains its atmosphere of faded Ritziness.And still attracts the eccentric-older Eastern Europeans sit sipping coffee whilst slipping pieces of praline gateau to small dogs on their laps and others still argue softly as though settling questions of long forgotten international importance.The restaurant has been little changed in decor over the years and retains a very traditional Polish feel as well as one of faded past glory.Wonderfully atmospheric.UPDATE DEC 2011.Alas this restaurant has now been taken over by a chain and now looks like a hundred others.It has lost its loyal clientele and iconic status.What a shame-one of the great restaurants of South Ken.

st7eFJjdeReCEUZxHjykcg.text: Definitely the best meal I have had in London.  We arrived around 9:30 and they managed to squish a space for us without a reservation.  The staff were super nice - so accommodating and friendly, and we had some great conversations with them.  Very attentive and quick to clear plates off our table as well.  Loved how they ladled the food straight from the pot or pan - it was nice.  The decor - lots of character - tiled walls and I know it would be fun to have a party here.The food - definitely the best food I've had in London, and most certainly the best Polish food I have ever had.  Amazing ingredients and taste.  The pierogies were out of this world (cheese and onion and potato) and I also had some amazing borscht.  My boyfriend had the beef which was tender and who knew vegetables in broth - cabbage, carrots, leeks - could be so tasty?  I will return many many times.  Yum!

LVE_kSOFV8qatEwPlARBYQ.text: Fantastic cabbage rolls and pierogies served in cast-iron skillets directly to your plate.  One of the best meals we had in London and conveniently located near the also fantastic Natural History Museum.The only thing preventing this from being a five-star review are the numerous fruit flies and somewhat dirty-looking dumbwaiter the food is hauled up on which looks like it could use either a paintjob or a thorough scrubbing.  The rest of the place is very posh.

RclSp6VI9IBjHkRd_QJWFg.text: coming here for years. food is simple polish done very well and plated at your table. excellent choices include herrings in cream sauce, salmon with pancakes, pierogi various fillings, calves liver, polish eggs and veal main. full choice of polish vodka and beers. honey vodkas go do very easy.service very attentive and not intrusive. highly recommended reasonable prices for high quality.

GS_DctdIB57MjZjFPLn_qw.text: Pics@Chopstix2steakniveschopstix2steaknives.blog… Have you ever read someone's dining experience and it just gets you so excited that you have to head there like almost immediately?This was what happened when I read this on The London Foodie blog. When I was in Poland, we had a nice little lady who cooked lunch for us everyday and it was simple and delicious home cooked food. In fact, I loved her home cooked food slightly more than the restaurants that I went to. So you bet I have fond memories of Polish food.So I was really excited to read about a Polish restaurant and I zipped down there at the earliest opportunity. So it was a group of us who settled in for dinner.First coursePierozki £9.5A few of us ordered the Pierozki with some choosing meat and some going with cheese. There isn't one that is better than the other; I think it is more a case of which filling appeals to you more. I preferred the cheese version more but it was a mixed vote on the choice of fillings.The dumplings did not have a thick or doughy skin which allowed the flavours of the fillings to shine through. Clean and tasty.Barszcz £6S ordered the Barszcz and this was well received. Mildly sweet and hearty.Second courseKura w rosole  £13Kaczka pieczona £19The Kura w rosole is tender cuts of chicken on the bone, served in a slow cooked broth. Dished with home made noodles, lemon sauce and broth vegetables. The Kaczka Pieczona is a roast duck that has been stuffed with apples and served with boiled potatoes, cranberries and red cabbage stewed in red wine with fried fruitsIt's quite a refreshing change when you get a bunch of waiters coming out to slice, plate and serve you in front of your eyes. I love the theatrical part of it. Like this order of beef tartare and it was made right in front of you. It really adds an element of understated charm.Eating here brought back fond memories of my visit to Poland. This is not fine dining but serves unpretentious honest food.

c5RYnSIXUezGPBESxZk_hA.text: The food was good, but the service was crap. The food was quite good. I had the pork aspic, mixed pierogis, and the schnitzel. All were well seasoned and prepared.The service was not so good. I was pressured to order literally the moment I sat down. I had no napkin at my table and had to flag down a waiter to bring one well into the first course. I was brought an alcohol menu and when I tried to order I was told their liquor license had expired. Most of the meal it was difficult to get a waiter and once I paid the bill they basically shunned me. I wasn't really feeling the love, I guess.In any case, I'd go again. It could have just been a off night for the staff.

mrsSqDSbIanNQihIhoUboA.text: Delicious food, awesome service and presentation and we had fun discussing who might be a spy trading secrets. Gessler is on my top 10 list of best meals EVER! I will be back whenever I'm in London.

F4Wxw6_0nt-msiUkMLiK5A.text: A beautiful food in a great place. I truly loved the attentive and polite service. Also, my Golabki alongside with mashed potatoes were great, it was too pricey though. I was not too happy to hear there was no proper Polish dessert, I mean baked one. We were offered a Sacher cake, pankcakes or a sweet - fruity - version of dumplings...hm, no thank you. However, I will be definitely coming back to see if the pastry chef is back.

rUoyQVvpM7OfXZi2VooAMQ.text: Went here today for lunch after visiting the Natural History Museum nearby. Was fairly busy at 2pm had to wait about 5 minutes or so to be seated...but it was worth it. It looks dowdy from outside but it is really cool inside. It feels really authentic, nothing fancy but cosy.I ordered Pork Goulash and my other half had veal meatballs with  dill sauce. we were both really impressed with our dishes. The goulash was totally different to versions I've made at home out of recipe books...it was served on a bed of barley (or bulgar wheat or something) with a side of beetroot. Both main courses cost around £11.The absolute best thing about this place is that the old polish dude who presumably cooked the dish serves it to you at the table out of the little saucepans etc it was cooked it. Honestly, he brought all the pans over to the table and just ladled it out onto your plate! That's what i do at home! It was very exciting!

0LMH1PLJ-tmXfSGiHFTFTw.text: Don't be fooled by the rather old-fashioned interior, the food is amazing and the service great. The soups especially are a treat, but make sure you have plenty of room for second course as well. Can't wait to try more delights from its menu.

7cN-h3zpysRNFqYBlFDViA.text: This definitely is a gem! We came for saturday dinner and love it. the staff is wonderful and authentic, the food is simple but delicious and the vodka strong. In case you make it to Warsaw, that's where the Gessler family emporium has their main restaurants. WONDERFUL!

O8st8LfmUgxvU1HF4UFucw.text: Simply the best steak tartare I've had in London!

WA0CTldfjZTICWma0MAzyA.text: Based on these reviews me and a friend decided to visit this place for a late lunch. I ordered Chicken Ceaser salad but it wasn't as good as I was expecting from these reviewers

oEtO7HejUZgC9smKLtKU1w.text: Such a charming Polish cafe.  For beginners, try the Polish platter which comes with sample of the common Polish dishes. Pierogi, golabki, bitkos and pancakes. I like the kielbasa and barszcz (beetroot soup) A truly authentic Polish spread. Must try the Polish beer & vodka. Don't let the Soviet decor scare you, the owners are very welcoming. This place used to be a meeting point for Polish exiles back in the 1930s.  Simple deco but food is przym!

X-snrZsxW9sYf0mkt9phEw.text: A new cuisine for us, and a wonderful introduction.The service was exceptionally friendly and attentive. It seemed to me they were wtriving for five star service but were not quite sure how to do it. Rather than annoying, it struck our group as endearing and altogether more attractive than had we been at a true five star venue. The staff genuinely desired to please, and they did.The food seemed traditional to our untutored palates. We enjoyed every dish. We will return!

Myp5dSa1g6JwIg6leg-5Bg.text: It's a shame that this London institution has changed, because it used to be so good. Now it simply typifies the general feel of restaurants in the area, serving up over priced and, frankly speaking, not up to par fair. I still really struggle to find somewhere worthwhile to eat in SW7 and I picked this, along with my father for a brief sunday encounter. Unfortunately my forebodings were confounded and I knew we should have gone elsewhere, when half cooked dumplings came to the table. I could have done better myself at home! And when the single dessert option "Polish Pancakes" turned up it didn't get much better. If you want a slice of Poland in London, I would visit newer places, that bring fresh blood, and if you want the smell of old, then go to Wodka in High St Ken. I wont be hurrying back here any time soon, and I wouldn't recommend you do either. Definitely a case of "it ain't what it used to be".

oOP07gzgzesqrTFFxPXnJg.text: This was more than just good food, but also bit of a dining experience to use that worn cliche. The food was excellent and authentic from my limited experience of Polish food. The way the chefs stroll out of the kitchen to serve the cuisine was a lovely personal touch and memorable. It's the best veal I had in London so far.

j5HTJ2jXeAWcDUMmHs5RuQ.text: Great food, attentive staff and a welcome break from the tourist hordes. Dramatically plating the food at the table was OTT but overall experience was very good.

JXgFOiz-oTCMKuNGMDGjiA.text: Simply put: Spectacular.  Thanks to the other Yelpers who pointed me here, because otherwise I would have missed out.  Friendly, low key, and the food was prepared tableside and excellent.  I had the marinaded herring followed by the roast duck stuffed with apples, and it was simply some of the finest food I've had.  Everying seems simply prepared with fresh ingredients (I spent my last 10 minutes sipping bison grass vodka, watching a chef prepare steak tartare from a fresh piece of steak - no shortcuts here!) and it really shows in the flavors and textures.  I lived in London for 10 years, and am really disappointed that I only now discovered Daquise.

iSEb87nrz3XBkhVx1sz2WQ.text: Although this restaurant was closed a little while back following a fire, the subsequent refurbishment hasn't changed the atmosphere. The decor is old-fashioned in a relaxed, evolved-over-the-years way, comforting and not at all fancy. In fact, that would be a fair description of the food too: it's substantial, tasty and traditional. I love the vegetarian platter, a mixture of cabbage, mushroom and potato-based dishes which is somehow deeply satisfying. You can drop in for tea and pastries, or settle down to work your way through the vodka menu over dinner. Service is pleasant and prices are reasonable. A good place to relax after visiting the nearby museums.

2m6zVhp6vCiicIxOz6vI-Q.text: I went here all the time when I was studying in London - it has a fun, comfortable atmosphere and good food.

YQ_J6GdfinNCSNQ6zcmB0w.text: Very close to South Kensington station, there are plenty of restaurant options near by.  Put this one on the top of your list to visit, the food is great!  I had tried to get a table without a reservation, but it wasn't possible, they were too busy, so go on their website and fill out the form (a bit old school nowadays with so many apps letting you book tables easily online).  We tried the dumplings (meat and cheese) for starter and they were delicious - I preferred the cheese ones but both were really good.For the main course we all got something different - beef stroganoff which was good (though I'd try something else next time), the schnitzel was very filling and then pork tenderloin mustard & honey with gnocchi.  That last dish was the best and I would probably go for that next time.  As portions are quite filling, there was no room dessert!

wXF9ZxUds2jAyzG-Lep5bQ.text: Wow talk about coming across a fantastic restaurant. I have never had Polish food before. This restaurant was a fantastic treat and a hidden gem. The staff and management is extremely friendly and knowledgeable with great recommendations. I will have to say the foods and appetizers that they recommend it was the best. Another unique thing about this restaurant is that they will bring the food to your table and serve it on to your plate. Some of the food is prepared right in front of you like this steak tartare which is one of my favorite dishes. I also loved the duck. My daughter tried the beef stroganoff and it was lovely. My wife tried did venison and it was incredible. Side dishes that accompanied the meals like mashed potato and beets or egg noddles and pasta was out of this world. This restaurant was so good and The food was so tasty, which makes me want to go back this week to try more items. Also we had I Apple Fritters  for dessert and it was fantastic.The prices are extremely reasonable . This restaurant also has a fantastic selection of wines and beers,both local and Polish. I also learned a lot about Polish food and the history of this restaurant one of the oldest restaurants in London and the oldest polish restaurant in London.DAQUISE Is the best restaurant experience I've had in a long time. DAQUISE has great ambience and The best food I've tried in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Duck with mashed potato Apple and cherry sauce
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Venison

nd_B6YXTKVnsOjGMuDdc7A.text: Wanting a restaurant near the Royal Albert Hall we found this one off Yelp and with great reviews. Polish food is not one of those foods a lot of people are usually in the mood for, maybe because they don't know what it consists of? However we decided to try it, OMG we were not at all disappointed, upon walking in the restaurant is quaint, neat and orderly and the ambiance is awesome. The service was above par so if that was any indication of things to come then we were in for a good one. We ordered the cabbage rolls, beef stroganoff, veal with cream sauce and the pork tenderloins in honey must and sauce (pictures will be posted). To say it was amazing is an understatement but seriously it was. As sides we got the carrots and the red and green cabbage. The chef brings your dishes from the basement (where the kitchen is located) and then him and his staff prepare the dishes near your table, it's super cool and unique. We loved the entire experience and made sure to let our waitress know to give our complements to the chef. If you are in the area, be sure to try this place

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Jello like dessert with vodka dressing
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Pancake dessert
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Outside

vmV4kZDsK10Db-yF8ZsRzQ.text: Alan and I first ate here 10 years ago and liked it.  Characteristically, I forgot and he remembered.  Even when he reminded me, it wasn't until he mentioned its proximity to the South Kensington Underground station that I remembered.  We walked over from the hotel w/o reservations, arriving about 6:30, and were lucky to be given a table.  Usually people in London eat later than that, but there was a concert in the area and at least three tables were heading to the concert.We were given menus and the cold beetroot soup and the duck stuffed w/ apples on the specials menu appealed to me.  Alan ordered an assortment of dumplings to start and the pork tenderloin as his main.  Bread was offered gratis and it was delicious, dense and crusty.  Butter accompanied it.  My soup was brought to the table in a tureen by the chef and was ladled into the waiting bowl.  It was a pale pink, probably from sour cream, and full of grated beets.  It was a generous portion and it was sublime.  I shared some w/ Alan, but finished the rest.  Alan gave me a taste of one of his dumplings and it was very good.  Our mains arrived, Alan's pork accompanied by gnocchi-like pillows and a grated carrot salad.  My duck was accompanied by lovely mashed potatoes and red cabbage.  The duck was tasty, w/ crunchy skin and moist meat which contrasted well w/ the soft apples.  The cabbage was warm and nicely seasoned.  Alan found his pork a bit dry.  He liked my mashed potatoes and I loved the taste of his carrot salad, which was intensely fresh and sweet.We chatted a little w/ the concert goers to our right and the two tables beyond them, also headed for the concert, chatted w/ each other and the people next to us.  It was the most cross-table talk I can remember seeing in a restaurant.  Most patrons seemed to be regulars.  The couple next to us certainly were.  One woman at a table by the front window, as she left, promised to return sooner than 35 years.  It was a very pleasant dinner.

i4qv32mS0LrxurcEyv-hOw.text: When you walk into this restaurant it feels like going back in time in the old Poland, as the decor is really spot on to create the atmosphere.the food is good, really good. The staff is friendly and the service is impeccable. I have been here a couple of times and tried various things off the menu and have always been satisfied. In particular the venison was remarkable.Not on the cheap side, but worth it. They also have some real polish vodka shots!

7pTw5TWDwqDCiM7VQ7_1og.text: Each visit to Daquise thrills my tastebuds and reminds me of my Polish roots. So happy to know that this veritable South Kensington institution is still thriving! Comfort food meets haut cuisine - on my last visit their wild boar pierogi and placki (potato pancakes) with smoked salmon were just sublime!

_0LLjc_CLztgmVMGTiXlxQ.text: The restaurant had a nice feel to it as soon as I walked in.  It looks homely and comfortable.  I noticed that the waiters were bringing out saucepans of food, which they dished out to the plates.  You don't often see this service in restaurants.  It's great - you almost have the feeling that you are at a dinner party and the host is serving you your dinner.We actually chose to come here to try Polish food, which is a new experience for us.  The meals were great.  I got the borscht with mini dumplings and my fiancée had the dumplings.  The borscht had a refreshing beetroot flavour.  For our mains, my fiancée got the roasted goose stuffed with buckwheat and I chose the veal escallops sautéed with tomato, garlic, white wine and cream.  I enjoyed my meal and luckily had room to try some of the goose too.The waiter helpfully explained each of the desserts on offer.  They had a selection of cakes and I asked for a slide of the chocolate tart.  It came filled with layers of jam and a crisp icing, it was morish. I could have eaten another slice even though it would have put me beyond full. My fiancée got the strawberry dumplings, which had an interesting taste: sweet from the strawberries, but a subtle savory aftertaste.After we paid the bill, we could choose a shot of liquor, which was a welcome surprise.  I chose one based on hops and honey.  It went down well and it was a good way to round off the meal.It was a great dinner out.  I would recommend it as something good to try and we are keen to try more Polish food now.

D4fGCdGBK0xUFEjnkMsasQ.text: Thank you, yelp, for directing me to this lovely place!I'd just left the V&A, busted out the yelp app, and what do you know?  Gessler at Daquise pops up with excellent reviews.  And let me tell you, each good review is totally well-deserved!Walked in at about 7:50ish pm on Friday night.  I was sat immediately, but I noticed towards 9:00, the restaurant was really booming, so if you want a later dinner, I'd definitely recommend calling ahead.  My knowledge of Polish food up to this point extended to sausage and not much else, so I didn't know quite what to expect.I ordered faaaar too much food for one person!  For starter, I ordered the pierogis, and tried a mix of the meat and the cheese/potato/onion.  Imagine my surprise when the chef brought them over to serve tableside!  (I'd only looked at the star-ratings, so missed the others who mentioned the tableside service)  The pierogis were delicious and covered in a buttery sauce with bacon.For the main, I ordered the roast duck, stuffed with apples, and served with cranberries, mash, and cabbage.  Everything was perfection.  Duck, again, cut tableside.  So tender and well-cooked with just a bit of crispy skin... I was tediously picking every bit of deliciousness clean of the bone, it was so good!Such a good find!  I intend to visit several times.

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Pierogi!
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Roast duck stuffed with apples!

OtluVG021nab3Ah-Ef7QYw.text: +Great Pierrogi+Great Borsh+ Very friendly service+ Historic and extremely interesting interiorIn my opinion the best Polish place in London

ahf4R_rv_L0bREs26eTxIQ.text: I do not have a single complaint about this restaurant. My mom and I came for lunch on a Saturday. The service was on point, they were very attentive and genuinely wanted us to enjoy the food. We had dumplings for starters and then I had a veal scallops and my mother a small chicken. What can I say. One of the best meals we've had in London. My veal scallops sauce was wonderful I almost wanted another whole bowl. And my mother says this is the best chicken she's had in a restaurant. Absolutely amazing meal and I will definitely be coming back. P.S. We loved the way our food was served! Original and personal.

nQjTXZq_BlKDOfTIwuzTuQ.text: I come here all the time. This little restaurant has a lot of history. Though the decor isn't anything hugely exciting, this adds to the experience - you're here for the food. And there's something about the large mirrors and raw walls that evoke the 1930s but in a wounded way; perfect for this cuisine; and the high ceilings are beautiful. I love the location, tucked away, the last building before the underground rolls past (you can watch the trains from the window in the back bit if you're into that haha).It's all about the steak tartare for me. Prepared in front of you, it's simply a must. Love most things on the menu though... The duck is my standard delicious choice for a main but the breaded veal is excellent too. If you want something special ask for jajka faszerowane.The vodka must be tried as well. This is something not fully appreciated in the UK; a shot usually served at room temp and usually some kind of abomination like Smirnoff. At Daquise ask the waiter for a recommendation and they will serve you a variety of proper vodkas, ice cold and in frosted shot glasses as they should be. The honey vodka is my personal favourite but take the opportunity to be a bit adventurous ;)

2LX34mxAU9UbrbPTChAObg.text: Fantastic food!Very impressed by the food, absolutely delicious and comforting! Atmosphere is with a twist of a post-WWII times. Very friendly service: feels like coming for dinner to one of your good relatives. When your food is ready, it's served on your plate by chefs themselves - a great touch! Very highly recommended! estonianfoodie.com

d8LgFlUQwuhaGVG8vDOzFg.text: Just can't give it 4 stars, although the salmon tartar would definitely get 4. When compared to Tatras (5 stars) and Patio (4+ stars) off Shepherds Bush, this is simply a 3. The place is clean, bright and comfortable and the staff is excellent, but the food is simple Polish home cooking. It lacked a uniqueness that sets it apart (except for the salmon). My wife (has Polish grandmother and grew up with this cuisine as her comfort food) concurs.

BrU4hyvxKOLj01wVCRZ4KQ.text: There might be a part of you that isn't sure about spending this much money in a place that doesn't have a sleek look.  Don't listen to that part of yourself.  I had a fabulous meal here, and wish I could go back and do it all again.  Started with honey and herb vodka.  A beautiful Amber color and served in an ice cold glass, I would have gone through more than one if it hadn't been for an early flight the next day. Had pirogies, some with cabbage and some with cheese, which the chef transfers directly from his pan onto your plate.  The pirogies were very soft, and happily coated in sautéed onions. I shudder to think about how many I could have eaten.Then the duck.  It's served along with sweet apples, which I wasn't expecting much from, but after the first bite I was surprised by just how good they were.  Same with the mashed potatoes, which tasted very fresh, and not at all buttery.  Had forgotten that mashed potatoes could be more than a forgettable side dish.  If the duck wasn't the juiciest preparation I've ever had, it makes for one memorable combination on the plate with the apples and potatoes. Lastly, the apple cake, which they say they make themselves, was the only appropriate end to a very hearty meal.  If you have a chilly evening free and an appetite, head right to this place.  After your meal you'll walk back out into the night air feeling very content.

f29eRf14bp3Mi81In9Z55w.text: This place was good...but didn't blow me away. I'm surprised by the rave reviews, but maybe that's why I feel like it didn't live up to expectations.We wanted a good dinner on our first night in London and ended up here based on a reviews. The restaurant itself nothing to look at...in fact there is one wall with extensive water damage to it. Our table was very wobbly, but the waiter put some folded paper under to stop it from rocking, so that was nice of him. We ordered pierogis as a starter and these were excellent. We were asked which type we wanted and when we hesitated the waiter said we could try two of each kind and so we did. That was really good. I had the "Tender chicken in pot", which was chicken boiled in broth and served with veggies and homemade noodles. My husband ordered veal meatballs in dill sauce. My husband's was definitely the better of the two dishes. I found my meal lacked flavour. The chicken was nicely cooked, but not seasoned especially well. The broth was very standard chicken broth, similar to what I would make at home and the noodles were a nice texture, but lacked flavour. Dave's meal was considerably more flavourful. At the end we waited to ask for the bill, as the waiter talked with a couple for fifteen minutes. We finally had to interrupt their conversation to ask for the bill.I DID like that we coud watch as some meals were prepared fresh near the middle of the restaurant. They seemed to have a sort of hot plate station set up. They didn't make everything there, just plated items.I have no doubt to the freshness of the food, but the overall experience didn't quite cut it for me. I wouldn't be opposed to trying it again, but since I'm not in London very often, I would probably be inclined to give something else a try first.

KWHvB_wBblmkI5OuS1MGvQ.text: Stumbled across the restaurant one night for dinner and it didn't disappoint. Everything was incredibly fresh. Will definitely be back.

ymcNn9HYgs5N9_LajMbkcQ.text: Went on Saturday night again -- we were initially supposed to be 6, but ended up at 4 sitting at a 6 man table. Table was a bit big, and the chandelier was quite bright so it sort of lost that cosy feel.I had the famous duck which was great, but definitely preferred my beef consomme dish from the previous visit (which was stupendous).Desert crepe things were still excellent, as was the vodka.  Love this spot.

wlddRcjdS0y5EbGy21st2g.text: I got stuck in a bit of a down pour on a cold london afternoon. I had no idea what sort of restaurant I was ducking into but it looked inviting from the exterior. The host seemed a little annoyed at having to seat a solo diner but I got a nice table that allowed for plenty of people watching.The service was very attentive and they answered all my questions about the menu without any hesitation. The mixed salad was fresh and quite tasty as well as the reasonable priced house wine of which I had a couple glasses. The menu was a bit limited but the entrees were quite varied. The main course I chose was the veal which was spectacular. I especially liked the way that the chef comes out to your table and plates the fresh off the stove food right in front of you. That was a very nice experience and gave me an opportunity to chat with him as he placed my meal in front of me. I don't think I have ever had that happen before.After the meal I was given the choice of several authentic Polish vodkas to choose from as an after dinner drink. The one I chose was bitter sweet, but tasty.In the end the bill was quite high, but I didn't mind because of the enjoyable dining experience.

zlwU6GEtgOdSSPc5o1uTBQ.text: I love this little gem by the South Ken tube station. Excellent food - the pierogies are served directly from the pan, and the tender chicken in pot is served with an incredible sauce and nice chewy noodles.

sezpIzae_Dj7k0IyZbd3CQ.text: Have you ever read someone's dining experience and it just gets you so excited that you have to head there like almost immediately?  This was what happened when I read this on The London Foodie blog. When I was in Poland, we had a nice little lady who cooked lunch for us everyday and it was simple and delicious home cooked food. In fact, I loved her home cooked food slightly more than the restaurants that I went to. So you bet I have fond memories of Polish food.  So I was really excited to read about a Polish restaurant and I zipped down there at the earliest opportunity. So it was a group of us who settled in for dinner.  First coursePierozki £9.5A few of us ordered the Pierozki with some choosing meat and some going with cheese. There isn't one that is better than the other; I think it is more a case of which filling appeals to you more. I preferred the cheese version more but it was a mixed vote on the choice of fillings.  The dumplings did not have a thick or doughy skin which allowed the flavours of the fillings to shine through. Clean and tasty.  Barszcz £6S ordered the Barszcz  and this was well received. Mildly sweet and hearty. Second courseKura w rosole - £13Kaczka pieczona £19The Kura w rosole is tender cuts of chicken on the bone, served in a slow cooked broth. Dished with home made noodles, lemon sauce and broth vegetables. The Kaczka Pieczona is a roast duck that has been stuffed with apples and served with boiled potatoes, cranberries and red cabbage stewed in red wine with fried fruits  It's quite a refreshing change when you get a bunch of waiters coming out to slice, plate and serve you in front of your eyes. I love the theatrical part of it. Like this order of beef tartare and it was made right in front of you. It really adds an element of understated charm.  Eating here brought back fond memories of my visit to Poland. This is not fine dining but serves unpretentious honest food.

gw0m9Od94sEVQvraY0cJmA.text: Such a simple place with excellent food. We had the cold beet soup, which I wish I could make at home here in Los Angeles. The potato salad and kielbasa made the perfect lunch. My partner had the stewed chicken and salad. I'm still dreaming about the rye bread and can't wait to go back for schnitzel! Lovely location near V & A and South Ken tube.

s5M13E0By3xQz2sQtDjGww.text: A pleasant little find! There were three of us & luckily got there just before the dinner rush on a Thursday night, otherwise I assume we would have needed reservations as it was pretty busy when we left. Cool ambiance, great food! The table side food prep was fun! Only two things prevented me from giving 5 stars; the young man who served us was a little rude & impatient and the house phone ring was strangely loud. Two of us had the pork tenderloin & one had the cod special. All very good!!!!

khWGqTwltOn23WhkOyvUqw.text: There is certainly no shortage of food available to people in Kensington and Daquise is proof that no matter what type of food you are in the mood for, you will be able to find it.  We were growing tired of the typical fare available in Kensington and I'd been to Daquise before and thought, why not give it a try again... I'm very glad we did.Polish cuisine is not foreign to me (call it my Jewish, Eastern European roots), but food cooked by Poles living in Britain is certainly unique.  The restaurant is large and airy, light pours in the windows (even when the sun is struggling to find its way out from the clouds) and the people in the restaurant are from all walks of life.  Whether you go to Daquise for business or pleasure, there is nothing about the menu too complicated that you would need help from the staff (and nothing so simple that you would think you were at an American-style chain restaurant), but the menu is easy and the wait staff and cooks (who deliver your food right out of the pans in which your food was cooked near your table) are unwilling or unable to explain.We've dined at every type of establishment: from devilishly simple Starbucks and Pret A Manger for a quick bite to the most formal affair that requires jacket and tie, we've done it.  That said, Daquise was wonderful and truly captured Eastern European, Polish fare with the type of service you'd expect in a fine restaurant in Warsaw.  The best thing at Daquise is that the fine fare does not come with a requirement for anything more than being casually dressed and expectant of wonderful food.We started with pierogi stuffed with cabbage and others with cheese, brought hot to the table from a woman in the kitchen whose Polish was so crisp that one could tell that she and her associates had experience with this food. The dumplings were followed by our lunch course that was made up of a lovely schnitzel with fried egg (something I'd missed since my last visit to Hungary), lovely sides of everything from mashed potatoes and dill with roasted vegetables, and a lovely beef simmered in bouillon with horseradish and a large bowl of broth left at the table to keep these morsels of loveliness moist.Our meal ended with apple fritters with jelly that one could tell came right out of the iron and came from a kitchen turning out food as orders came in.  We left delighted by this little restaurant and are looking forward to the return.  People came in and out as we ate and many simple had an appetizer as a snack to continue on with their shopping and walking in South Kensington.  We were on a mission that day that would take us from the tube stope in S. Kensington to do a bit of shopping, but the sun was out and we really wanted the walk so we ate, walked on to shop at Harvey Nichols (we pass on ever entering Harrods and intentionally walk on back streets to miss the crowds), but we had the energy to do it because the good people at Daquise fed us well and we cleaned our plates on good, hearty food that one struggles to find in a place like Kensington where (let's face it) portions are typically small and restaurants typically filled with people whose style of service is Western and many think they're simply too good for the posts they currently hold.Daquise is worth the stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Dessert: apple fritters with jam to round out a lunch for a hearty day.
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. A lovely schnitzel as big as a plate with a side of dill mashed and carrots.
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Pierogis hot from the stove, served by the chef. A lovely piece of Eastern Europe in South Kensington.

1Uobba0Ot6YXtWzBjLf3Bw.text: I have been to my fair share for snobby pretentious places in London with a ridiculous price tag that makes you think the food is laced with ambrosia when really, it's not even worth a fraction of what it costs. This is not one of those places.The atmosphere is a bit understated but classy in its simplicity. Depending on the time you get here, it may or may not be packed. My friend and I arrived at around 6:30 and it was almost completely empty. By 7:30 it was completely full.The menu appears a bit too simple at first glance- nothing special- and the prices might seem way too high for the kind of fare that you're eating. But trust me when I say that it is all freaking amazing! You have to start with a glass of wine. They have superb quality that whets the appetite and prepares you for the meal to come.Every ingredient is made to compliment the main dishes perfectly. The Venison Medallions, for example, come drenched in a bed of cranberry sauce which makes the meat slightly sweet and deliciously tender. It comes with a serving of dumplings which are essentially gnocchi, with a chewy consistency and a hearty finish.For dessert, you absolutely HAVE to get the Pancakes with Cheese and Raspberry Compote. It's essentially a crepe, but it is unlike any crepe you've ever had. Slightly sweet, crispy, soft, chewy, and light. It's the perfect finish to a scrumptious meal.Yes, it's a bit pricey. But for just over 30 pounds, you can dine like a CEO on a slightly special day. Totally worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Pretty fancy.
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Post-Meal Cappuccino

Mtr4MC_hVXhtM7NBjSLAbw.text: Absolutely lovely. While contemplating Cold War history (you'll have to do your own research, they don't advertise it), you'll be served a delicate and flavorful cold beet soup by the chef - wonderfully seasoned with green onion and fresh herbs. The wild boar pierogi were delicate and flavorful, the wild boar goulash was melt in your mouth tender and was also brought to the dining room to be plated by the chef. Dessert simply must be the apple turnovers -warm and crispy, not too sweet. The service was among the best we found in London, attentive and prompt. The decor is old world elegant but not fussy and the old hewn wooden floor has seen some serious history. A true delight.

dzoa06r6p_lQONrRXgMgRA.text: My husband and I had an absolutely incredible meal at Daquise in South Kensington. We walked in without a reservation and were very happy to be accommodated with what looked to be the only available table that wasn't already reserved. So I'd suggest calling ahead to secure a table.  We started with a bottle of wine and the kielbasa and pierogies. At our server's suggestion, we were able to do a mix of all three pierogi varieties. The kielbasa was served over crispy fried onions with spicy mustard. Both starters were excellent and I'd be hard pressed not to order them again on a future visit. For my main, I had the beef stroganoff while my husband had the veal schnitzel, which was so tender you could cut it with a fork. It was fantastic and served with mounds of whipped potatoes and topped with a fried egg. My stroganoff was served with homemade egg noodles and was delicious in its own right, though the schnitzel definitely won out. There was no room for dessert but I have no regrets. That meal was one of my favorites of the year so far.

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom

THiH0N0VHJXALcexhnsaBQ.text: This place is excellent, right in south kensington, a stones throw from the tube station, you have to walk past it on the way back from The Natural History Museum or the V&A if you're choosing to use the underground, and that's why we ended up there. We hadn't reserved anything, but I would recommend to, we were there pretty early, and it really filled out as we were there. Dimly lit, and an odd mix of a little posh, and a little run down. The dumplings are excellent, as are the pierogies. For mains, Stroganoff and the venison. Excellent, and served from pots and pans on to your plate, with fab veggies and excellent smooth fluffy mash. A really cosy homely touch, and from excellent friendly staff.We were a little miffed when they didn't have either of the puddings that took our fancy when we'd decided to go all out, but what they suggested instead were excellent. I would definitely go back, and definitely recommend.

ZATEcUHslWvKfWC1WsdLGA.text: It was a random stop by on our way to another restaurant close by. We had never tried Polish food and thought it would be interesting to give it a shot here. We had some salmon, some dumplings, some soup and a ver interesting dessert made with rum (or vodka?) All the food were decently cooked and plated. The environment is a bit unique and was def a plus to our experience. A good find: )

L7rWb3uYHvVyUp5bVPn4Zw.text: We came here for dinner after a visit to the v&a. First and foremost, you need to reserve a table in advance. We booked a table for 21.00 and it wasn't really busy which meant it wasn't very loud. When you walk in you feel like you have been invited into someone's home. Food: we ordered meat and cheese dumplings. They were sooo good. It's a must. All 3 if us ordered different mains so we can try various plates. I hate the Snitzel with the egg which also came with carrots and it was really filling and yummy. I also tried a bit from the beef stroganoff and the pork honey & mustard. It was all very good. I think o preferred the honey &mustard dish. We were so full we had no room for dessert. Service: the service was good. They bring your food in pots and pans from the kitchen and serve you on the spot. The mash potatoes were not only made for me but others as well and the way they serve makes you feel like the meals are home-cooked. The waiter was a slow in general but really friendly I definitely recommend this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Beef stroganoff
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Pork with honey and mustard sauce
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom. Dumplings for starters

b_rAOx3C0R7gaLvD3FHGgw.text: I stay in Kensington for business once or twice a year. I am very much a creature of habit and rarely venture outside a three block radius from the hotel for dinner. This evening was a beautiful evening for a little walk, so I used Yelp and coin this restaurant. I am so glad I did! I started with potato pierogi sautéed with caramelized onion and parsley! Amazing! The serving size of 6 is meant to be shared, but I am so glad I didn't have to!My main course was a special pork loin in mushroom cream sauce with gnocchi. I love mushrooms and this did not disappoint! It also came with a side of beets. I did not grow up in a beet family and I am used to pickled beets being sour. So I was very unsure. I tried them and to my surprise they were warm, with a mulled spiced wine flavor, and slightly crisp! Amazing! I had a small glass of the house red, a Spanish Rioja, which was also very good, and cheap! They had a large wine and cocktail list, and a few polish beers to chose from?While I didn't have dessert, I saw several people get dessert and it looked amazing!I didn't have a reservation and they were quite busy, but they were so kind and squeezed me in between to couples that were so engrossed with each other they didn't notice me there! But if you have more than 2 I recommend reservations. The place is small, shotgun style restaurant. The kitchen is in the basement and they have a dumb waiter cabinet with the old pulley system on top! It has the look of an upscale restaurant, with the atmosphere of a casual family dinner restaurant, and he prices were very reasonable for the quantity and quality of the meal! I will be dining here again!

H8FBBvywGVZHmR3fUyV6NQ.text: Very pleasant "ethnic" Polish restaurant. Good quality fare with impeccable but friendly service.Definitely needs a try, you will want to go again once a year even if you live far like I do.Congratulations Guys...

c4nOMdPXupvs-297V6YP-g.text: Nice atmosphere, reasonably priced and interesting locale. The food, I believe, is not traditional. The Borscht was tasty but lacked substance and cabbage rolls had fresh dill which was a plus but the sauce they used detracted from the rolls themselves.The service was OK.

fIOY07qij0fNUmWNLni0KQ.text: Daquise in Kensington after a day trip to the V&A museum is something I would heavily recommend.The museum is my favourite in London and Daquise has so much history (spy hangout, Roman Polanski's favourite place etc etc) and the Polish food here is the best I have tried in town, each course paired with some phenomenal vodkas.Excellent range of Vodkas (my favourites were the hazelnut & the eggnog)Lovely heartwarming food. The way it was served, by the Chef at our table (the pierrogi & the Roast Duck) was like dinner theater and a meal served by a loving mum / aunt - all rolled into one.Simple Interiors. The shabby interior just adds to its charm. Wonderful Service.Love this place, will keep going back.

4BbH2zjHoyB6Sta2xjsIfw.text: One of my friends booked this restaurant and I didn't know what to expect since I had never had polish food. It was such a wonderful surprise from the way they present the food ( in pots and pans served at the table) to the food itself. All was beautiful!! I planning a second visit in the coming weeks for the dumplings and the rabbit!

58SnYks3ojMjS4vKUd-XIQ.text: Stopped here for a bit of a date night, and was very impressed. The place is high end without being stuffy; it was excellent for an intimate date, but would be just as good for a more rowdy group of friends!Food is excellent. They plate the food at your table, which is a really cool touch, so you get to see the chefs and see how they create the dishes you are eating. Dumplings (pierogies) were amazing. Softly stuffed, flavorful filling - we tried the cabbage, cheese and beef, all very different, all very excellent - perfect starter. It seems as though the food is actually made from scratch as well, the potato and egg noodles were excellent - pillowy soft, and just tender enough to make it seem fresh. Very well done.Service is good, though not overly friendly. They leave you to it, but are always around as you need them. Value was decent, really great food and atmosphere at a slightly higher price point. Was worth the trip to go there, would definitely do again.

photos.caption: Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Daquise - London, United Kingdom

nor865c3E0CPA7A5tLYK5A.text: Very good food, simple and tasty and well priced. Rather enjoyable. Started with the dumplings which were really good. Then had the rabbit, the pork medalions and veal schnitzel, all of were great. The dessert, apple friters, wow, simple and yet amazing. The order came out wrong, we ordered one portion but two came, they were so good we took the second portion!

9xt1z9GAoOP4Qbr7ovGxEg.text: Daquise is a quiet restaurant in busy South Ken. High ceilings yet relaxed and laid-back.Starters were tomato soup and traditional zurek. The latter was good but not sour enough and the former was nothing like Polish soup in Poland. Not recommended.Then we had potato pancakes with cured salmon, calves liver with apple and onions, boar pate and ruskie pierogi. Only the pate was not right....weird flavour but maybe just not to my taste. Calves liver was particularly excellent and the pierogi was my favourite of this variety in London so far. Potato pancakes were excellent too.Main courses were veal medallions, pork chop schnitzel and poached salmon. I wish the pork hadn't been flattened and kept thick and therefore juicier but it was still good. Mash good, cucumber salad needed more flavour. Apple fritters were enjoyed, home-made too!! The most exciting and lovely thing about this restaurant is that they bring pots with the food to the restaurant floor and serve you straight from the cooking pots!! Mash from one pot, veg from another, meat from a little frying pan.....so cool!! And they do this for every guest, however busy they are. I asked. Very commendable.Overall, a good experience, good service, can imagine the vibe of this restaurant is great when it's busy. It was good and it was quiet!!

E99Pv88eCTZ2pFwPJ_MD4Q.text: Once again, Yelp reviews come through for me.Started with the potato pancakes (latkes) with salmon. It was plated right in front of me. Owner (?) came over and gave me some sour cream, but it didn't really need it. It also didn't stop me from eating the sour cream.The pierogies showed me what they are supposed to be, light, filling and delicious. This is a GREAT restaurant that should be on your radar if you are ever around South Kensington. Highly recommend. I don't think it serves a wide variety of liquor, but don't let that stop you from coming here and enjoying this restaurant.

EXf0ZP0hbWT-LkxcjP5Xkw.text: Really solid spot. Nice Old World vibe. Great food. Ample portions. Tasteful music. Pretty efficient staff - and friendly. Definitely worth checking out.

H0OFx94oH2gc5hHHZkVmtw.text: Awesome Polish restaurant. Excellent service. Very busy dinner crowd.We had the summer beet soup - so good. I had the duck, which was great. My husband had the veal, which was excellent! Portions were huge.Good wine list. Cool decor & ambiance. It was nice and intimate until 9pm-ish when it got insanely busy! Staff were good, though.
